rsbNotes.title: Job 1:1–5
rsbNotes.text: 1:1–5 The prologue (1; 2) begins with a depiction of Job blessed by and devoted to his God.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:1
rsbNotes.text:
1:1 Uz. Uz was an extended region east of Judah, perhaps on the edge of the desert, but conducive to raising crops (v. 14) and livestock (v. 3). Job was not a nomad but an elder in a major town (29:7).

blameless and upright. This is ordinary language and does not mean that Job was sinless.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:3
rsbNotes.text: 1:3 sheep . . . camels . . . oxen . . . donkeys. Patriarchal wealth was measured by amount of livestock (cf. Gen. 30:43).

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:5
rsbNotes.text:
1:5 consecrate them. Job was rightly concerned for the spiritual welfare of his children.

offer burnt offerings. By this means of grace the patriarch Job, like Abraham (Gen. 15:9, 10), filled the role of priest for the family, consecrating his children to the Lord.

cursed God in their hearts. The Hebrew reads lit. “blessed God,” but that is a euphemism. Cursing God was a sin about which Job himself would be tested (v. 11).

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:6–2:13
rsbNotes.text: 1:6–2:13 The writer reveals the developments in heaven and their consequences on earth that led to Job’s suffering.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:6–12
rsbNotes.text: 1:6–12 This is the first of two scenes in heaven depicting the divine council and focusing on the encounter between God (Yahweh) and Satan. Satan is more than prosecutor. He opposes the will of God, in keeping with the role of the serpent in Gen. 3. In v. 9 he questions Job’s religious motive. The use of “Yahweh,” the covenant name of God, throughout chs. 1 and 2 (also in 38:1; 40:1; and ch. 42) indicates that God was in a covenant relation with Job in love and mercy from first to last.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:6
rsbNotes.text: 1:6 Satan. See theological note “Satan.”

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:8
rsbNotes.text: 1:8 Job is honored by God, who approves of him as a true and faithful servant, i.e., one keeping the solemn oaths of the covenant relationship. It is God, not Satan, who singles out Job for testing.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:11
rsbNotes.text: 1:11 Will Job, who was so sensitive to the possibility of his children cursing God, now sin that way himself?

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:12
rsbNotes.text: 1:12 The Adversary is allowed to test Job, but at this point, only with regard to his possessions and family. His power is restricted to what is permitted by the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:13–22
rsbNotes.text: 1:13–22 Despite Satan’s divinely-permitted (and divinely-limited) assaults on his possessions, servants, and children, Job remains steadfast in his belief that God is good.

rsbNotes.title: Job 1:20–22
rsbNotes.text: 1:20–22 Job utters a wisdom poem that portrays the wisdom of quiet submission to the secret will of God. Everything belongs to the Creator who gave it. God’s people must praise Him for whatever He does with what is His. The word “blessed,” (or “praised,” v. 21) is the same used in v. 11 for “cursed.” By using it here, the author is stressing how Job has frustrated Satan’s predictions in v. 11. But v. 22 implies the testing is not yet over.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:1–6
rsbNotes.text: 2:1–6 Further developments in heaven—another round of accusations from Satan—precede more suffering for Job on earth.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:3
rsbNotes.text: 2:3 holds fast his integrity . . . without reason. The sudden change from the words of 1:6–8 at the end of 2:1–3 shows how the Adversary, who has lost the first round, is humiliated by God through a bit of irony. The same word Satan had used to accuse Job is used here, translated “without reason.” It is the Adversary who has done wrong, not Job.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:4
rsbNotes.text: 2:4 Skin for skin. Satan is suggesting that even Job’s statement of faith in 1:21 is nothing but a ploy. He is willing to sacrifice anything for his own skin. If God will only stretch out His hand and strike Job’s body, then he would curse God to His face.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:6
rsbNotes.text: 2:6 spare his life. God permits the Adversary to be used as His instrument to strike Job. This brings up the problem of evil. Satan, as a creature, is reined in. He is allowed to go only as far as God permits. The word translated “spare” can be translated “safeguard”; it would appear that Satan is being held responsible for Job’s life.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:7–10
rsbNotes.text: 2:7–10 Despite Satan’s divinely-permitted (and divinely-limited) attacks on his body, Job holds firmly committed to his conviction that God is praiseworthy.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:7
rsbNotes.text: 2:7 loathsome sores. We have no way of knowing the exact nature of Job’s disease.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:8
rsbNotes.text: 2:8 sat in the ashes. Perhaps by trial and error the ancients learned that the ashes were a place where disease would not spread. Or it may simply have been a way of lamenting.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:9
rsbNotes.text: 2:9 Job’s wife was unaware of God’s guarantee that Job’s life would not be taken.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:10
rsbNotes.text:
2:10 foolish. The Hebrew word for “foolish” or “fool” has to do with faithlessness and religious apostasy, as in Ps. 14:1 (cf. 53:1). It is more an ethical judgment than an intellectual one.

Job did not sin with his lips. This stress on the purity of Job’s speech is an anticipation of the contrast that will come in the dialogue, where Job’s words are less pure.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:11–13
rsbNotes.text: 2:11–13 Job’s friends arrive to comfort him in the midst of his terrible suffering.

rsbNotes.title: Job 2:13
rsbNotes.text: 2:13 they sat with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him. This behavior, tied to the number of completeness (seven), expresses the most intense form of grief they could display. Near Eastern protocol demanded that Job should be the first to speak. For the practice of mourning seven days over the dead, see Gen. 50:10.

rsbNotes.title: Job 3–27
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–27:23 In three cycles of speeches, the writer explores human perspectives on Job’s suffering.

rsbNotes.title: Job 3
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–26 Job breaks the silence with a fiercely emotional lamentation. He expresses the same kind of depression that overtook the psalmist (Ps. 88) and also Jeremiah (Jer. 20:14, 15), whose bitter lament is, in language, similar to Job’s.

rsbNotes.title: Job 3:3–10
rsbNotes.text: 3:3–10 Job does not curse God, but he goes so far as to question God’s wisdom in giving him life.

rsbNotes.title: Job 3:11–26
rsbNotes.text: 3:11–26 Vv. 3–10 were set in the form of curses, while these are rhetorical questions. Job gives vent to his frustration, asking why he was not stillborn (vv. 11, 12, 16). Since that did not happen, his frustration moves on to ask rhetorically why he should not have experienced premature death (vv. 20, 23).
